environments.name: Arctic
environments.description: Frozen landscapes of ice and snow, including tundra and glaciers.

hazards.name: Extreme Cold
hazards.description: Extreme cold (below 0° Fahrenheit) deals 1d6 cold damage per hour to creatures without cold resistance or immunity.

hazards.name: Thin Ice
hazards.description: Creatures might fall through thin ice into freezing water. A creature that falls into freezing water must make a DC 10 Constitution saving throw or gain one level of exhaustion.

hazards.name: Avalanche
hazards.description: A creature in the path of an avalanche must make a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw or take 8d10 bludgeoning damage and be buried. A buried creature is restrained and begins to suffocate.

weatherTypes.name: Blizzard
weatherTypes.description: Heavy snowfall and strong winds reduce visibility to 5 feet and impose disadvantage on Perception checks that rely on sight or hearing.

weatherTypes.name: Clear and Cold
weatherTypes.description: Clear skies but extremely cold temperatures. Creatures must make a DC 10 Constitution saving throw every hour or gain one level of exhaustion.

weatherTypes.name: Snowfall
weatherTypes.description: Light to moderate snowfall reduces visibility to 30 feet and creates difficult terrain.

day.description: Bright sunlight reflecting off snow can cause snow blindness.

night.description: Temperatures drop severely at night, increasing the DC for Constitution saving throws against extreme cold by 5.

environments.name: Coastal
environments.description: Shorelines, beaches, cliffs, and areas where land meets sea.

hazards.name: High Tide
hazards.description: Rising tides can trap creatures against cliffs or in caves. Creatures caught in rising water must make a DC 10 Strength (Athletics) check to swim to safety or be swept out to sea.

hazards.name: Quicksand
hazards.description: Coastal quicksand appears as normal sand but can trap creatures. A creature that steps in quicksand sinks 1d4+1 feet and becomes restrained.

hazards.name: Rip Current
hazards.description: Strong currents that can pull swimmers away from shore. A creature caught in a rip current must make a DC 15 Strength (Athletics) check or be pulled 30 feet out to sea.

weatherTypes.name: Coastal Storm
weatherTypes.description: Heavy rain and strong winds reduce visibility to 30 feet and impose disadvantage on ranged attack rolls.

weatherTypes.name: Sea Fog
weatherTypes.description: Dense fog reduces visibility to 20 feet and imposes disadvantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on sight.

weatherTypes.name: Clear and Breezy
weatherTypes.description: Clear skies with a steady sea breeze. No adverse effects.

day.description: Bright sunlight reflecting off water can cause glare.

night.description: Coastal areas are often well-lit by moonlight reflecting off water, reducing penalties for darkness.

environments.name: Desert
environments.description: Arid regions with little rainfall, including both hot and cold deserts.

hazards.name: Extreme Heat
hazards.description: Extreme heat (above 100° Fahrenheit) deals 1d4 fire damage per hour to creatures without heat resistance or immunity.

hazards.name: Sandstorm
hazards.description: Blowing sand reduces visibility to 5 feet and deals 1d6 slashing damage per hour to unprotected creatures.

hazards.name: Dehydration
hazards.description: Creatures need twice as much water in desert environments. A creature that doesn't drink enough water must make a DC 15 Constitution saving throw or gain one level of exhaustion.

weatherTypes.name: Scorching Heat
weatherTypes.description: Extreme temperatures during the day cause creatures to make Constitution saving throws every hour or gain exhaustion.

weatherTypes.name: Sandstorm
weatherTypes.description: Blowing sand reduces visibility to 5 feet and deals 1d6 slashing damage per hour to unprotected creatures.

weatherTypes.name: Clear Skies
weatherTypes.description: Clear skies with intense sun. Creatures without proper protection must make a DC 10 Constitution saving throw every hour or gain one level of exhaustion.

day.description: Intense heat during the day increases the DC for Constitution saving throws against extreme heat by 5.

night.description: Temperatures drop significantly at night, potentially causing cold damage instead of heat damage.

environments.name: Forest
environments.description: Wooded areas ranging from light woodlands to dense, ancient forests.

hazards.name: Poisonous Plants
hazards.description: Contact with certain forest plants can cause irritation or poisoning. A creature that touches poisonous plants must make a DC 12 Constitution saving throw or take 1d10 poison damage.

hazards.name: Falling Branches
hazards.description: Strong winds or decaying trees can cause branches to fall. A creature in the area must make a DC 12 Dexterity saving throw or take 2d6 bludgeoning damage.

hazards.name: Entangling Vines
hazards.description: Thick vines can entangle creatures moving through the forest. A creature that fails a DC 13 Dexterity saving throw becomes restrained.

weatherTypes.name: Heavy Rain
weatherTypes.description: Heavy rainfall reduces visibility to 60 feet and creates difficult terrain in areas without tree cover.

weatherTypes.name: Forest Mist
weatherTypes.description: Mist among the trees reduces visibility to 30 feet and muffles sound.

weatherTypes.name: Clear and Pleasant
weatherTypes.description: Clear skies with dappled sunlight filtering through the trees. No adverse effects.

day.description: Sunlight filters through the canopy, creating areas of bright light and dim light.

night.description: Dense forest canopy blocks moonlight, making the forest darker than other environments at night.

environments.name: Grassland
environments.description: Open plains, savannas, and meadows covered primarily with grasses.

hazards.name: Wildfire
hazards.description: Dry grasslands are susceptible to wildfires. A creature caught in a wildfire takes 2d6 fire damage at the start of each turn.

hazards.name: Hidden Sinkholes
hazards.description: Sinkholes can be hidden by tall grass. A creature that steps on a sinkhole must make a DC 12 Dexterity saving throw or fall 10 feet and take 1d6 bludgeoning damage.

hazards.name: Stampede
hazards.description: Herds of animals can stampede when frightened. A creature in the path of a stampede must make a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw or take 3d6 bludgeoning damage and be knocked prone.

weatherTypes.name: Thunderstorm
weatherTypes.description: Lightning strikes are common in open grasslands. Each hour, there is a 10% chance a creature is targeted by a lightning strike, requiring a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw or taking 8d6 lightning damage.

weatherTypes.name: High Winds
weatherTypes.description: Strong winds in open grasslands impose disadvantage on ranged attack rolls and Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on hearing.

weatherTypes.name: Clear Skies
weatherTypes.description: Clear skies with good visibility. No adverse effects.

day.description: Open grasslands provide little shade during the day, potentially causing heat exhaustion.

night.description: Open grasslands allow for excellent visibility under moonlight, reducing penalties for darkness.

environments.name: Mountain
environments.description: Elevated terrain including foothills, mountain passes, and peaks.

hazards.name: Rockslide
hazards.description: Loose rocks can create dangerous slides. A creature in the path of a rockslide must make a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw or take 4d10 bludgeoning damage and be knocked prone.

hazards.name: Altitude Sickness
hazards.description: At high altitudes (above 10,000 feet), creatures must make a DC 10 Constitution saving throw or gain one level of exhaustion. The DC increases by 1 for every additional 1,000 feet.

hazards.name: Narrow Ledge
hazards.description: Traversing narrow mountain ledges requires a DC 10 Dexterity (Acrobatics) check. Failure means the creature falls.

weatherTypes.name: Mountain Storm
weatherTypes.description: Severe storms at high altitude include strong winds, lightning, and potentially snow or hail. Visibility is reduced to 20 feet, and creatures must make a DC 12 Strength saving throw or be knocked prone by the wind.

weatherTypes.name: Thick Fog
weatherTypes.description: Mountain fog reduces visibility to 10 feet and makes navigation difficult.

weatherTypes.name: Clear and Cold
weatherTypes.description: Clear skies but cold temperatures. At high altitudes, creatures without cold protection must make Constitution saving throws against extreme cold.

day.description: Intense sunlight at high altitudes can cause sunburn and snow blindness.

night.description: Temperatures drop severely at night, increasing the DC for Constitution saving throws against extreme cold by 5.

environments.name: Swamp
environments.description: Wetlands with shallow water and abundant vegetation, including marshes and bogs.

hazards.name: Quicksand
hazards.description: Swamp quicksand can trap unwary travelers. A creature that steps in quicksand begins to sink and becomes restrained. Each round, it sinks 1d4 feet deeper.

hazards.name: Poisonous Gas
hazards.description: Pockets of poisonous gas can form in swamps. A creature that enters such an area must make a DC 13 Constitution saving throw or take 3d6 poison damage.

hazards.name: Disease
hazards.description: Swamp water often carries disease. A creature that drinks unfiltered swamp water must make a DC 15 Constitution saving throw or contract a disease.

weatherTypes.name: Heavy Rain
weatherTypes.description: Heavy rainfall causes water levels to rise and creates difficult terrain throughout the swamp.

weatherTypes.name: Swamp Fog
weatherTypes.description: Dense fog reduces visibility to 10 feet and muffles sound.

weatherTypes.name: Humid and Muggy
weatherTypes.description: High humidity makes physical exertion more difficult. Creatures have disadvantage on Constitution checks and saving throws related to exhaustion.

day.description: Swamps are often shaded by vegetation, creating areas of dim light even during the day.

night.description: Bioluminescent fungi and insects provide small points of light in the darkness, creating an eerie atmosphere.

environments.name: Underdark
environments.description: Vast network of underground caverns, tunnels, and subterranean realms.

hazards.name: Cave-in
hazards.description: Unstable tunnels can collapse. A creature in the area of a cave-in must make a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw or take 4d10 bludgeoning damage and be buried and restrained.

hazards.name: Toxic Fungi
hazards.description: Spores from toxic fungi can cause hallucinations or poison. A creature that disturbs toxic fungi must make a DC 13 Constitution saving throw or be poisoned for 1 hour.

hazards.name: Tremors
hazards.description: Minor earthquakes can cause stalactites to fall. A creature in the area must make a DC 12 Dexterity saving throw or take 2d6 piercing damage.

weatherTypes.name: Toxic Gas Pocket
weatherTypes.description: Pockets of toxic gas can accumulate in low areas. Creatures that enter such areas must make a DC 15 Constitution saving throw or take 3d6 poison damage.

weatherTypes.name: Fungal Bloom
weatherTypes.description: Periodic blooms of fungal spores reduce visibility to 10 feet and can cause respiratory issues.

weatherTypes.name: Calm
weatherTypes.description: The typical still, silent atmosphere of the Underdark. No adverse effects.

day.description: There is no natural day/night cycle in the Underdark. Time is often measured by the growth cycles of fungi or the movements of underground creatures.

night.description: Same as day in the Underdark - perpetual darkness except for bioluminescent fungi and other light sources.

environments.name: Underwater
environments.description: Aquatic environments including oceans, seas, and large lakes.

hazards.name: Crushing Depths
hazards.description: At extreme depths (below 300 feet), water pressure can cause damage. A creature without pressure adaptation takes 1d6 bludgeoning damage per minute.

hazards.name: Strong Currents
hazards.description: Strong underwater currents can sweep creatures away. A creature caught in a strong current must make a DC 15 Strength (Athletics) check or be carried 60 feet in the current's direction.

hazards.name: Drowning
hazards.description: Creatures that cannot breathe underwater can hold their breath for a number of minutes equal to 1 + their Constitution modifier (minimum 30 seconds). After this time, they begin drowning.

weatherTypes.name: Underwater Storm
weatherTypes.description: Powerful currents and turbulent water reduce visibility to 10 feet and require Strength checks to swim against.

weatherTypes.name: Murky Water
weatherTypes.description: Sediment or algae blooms reduce visibility to 5 feet.

weatherTypes.name: Clear Water
weatherTypes.description: Unusually clear water allows visibility up to 60 feet.

day.description: Sunlight penetrates the water to varying depths, creating bright light near the surface that gradually dims with depth.

night.description: Darkness prevails underwater at night, except for bioluminescent creatures and features.

environments.name: Urban
environments.description: Cities, towns, and other densely populated settlements.

hazards.name: Crowds
hazards.description: Dense crowds can slow movement and make it difficult to track specific individuals. Movement speed is halved in crowded areas.

hazards.name: Pickpockets
hazards.description: Thieves may attempt to steal from characters in crowded areas. Characters must succeed on a DC 15 Wisdom (Perception) check to notice a pickpocket attempt.

hazards.name: Collapsing Building
hazards.description: Damaged or poorly constructed buildings can collapse. A creature in a collapsing building must make a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw or take 4d10 bludgeoning damage and be buried under rubble.

weatherTypes.name: Urban Downpour
weatherTypes.description: Heavy rain in urban areas creates slippery surfaces and can flood low-lying streets.

weatherTypes.name: Smog
weatherTypes.description: Industrial cities may experience smog that reduces visibility to 60 feet and can cause respiratory issues.

weatherTypes.name: Clear Skies
weatherTypes.description: Clear weather in an urban environment. No adverse effects.

day.description: Busy streets filled with people going about their business. Crowds can make movement difficult.

night.description: Streets are less crowded but potentially more dangerous. Certain districts may have increased criminal activity.

environments.name: Jungle
environments.description: Dense, tropical forests with high rainfall and biodiversity.

hazards.name: Poisonous Plants
hazards.description: Jungles contain many poisonous plants. A creature that touches certain plants must make a DC 13 Constitution saving throw or take 2d10 poison damage.

hazards.name: Quicksand
hazards.description: Hidden quicksand can trap unwary travelers. A creature that steps in quicksand begins to sink and becomes restrained.

hazards.name: Disease
hazards.description: Tropical diseases are common in jungles. A creature that is bitten by certain insects must make a DC 11 Constitution saving throw or contract a disease.

weatherTypes.name: Tropical Downpour
weatherTypes.description: Heavy rainfall reduces visibility to 20 feet and creates difficult terrain in low-lying areas.

weatherTypes.name: Oppressive Heat
weatherTypes.description: Extreme heat and humidity cause exhaustion. Creatures must make a DC 10 Constitution saving throw every hour or gain one level of exhaustion.

weatherTypes.name: Humid and Muggy
weatherTypes.description: Typical jungle weather with high humidity. No severe adverse effects.

day.description: Dense canopy filters sunlight, creating a mix of bright light, dim light, and darkness on the jungle floor.

night.description: Pitch darkness under the jungle canopy, with occasional bioluminescent fungi and insects providing small points of light.

environments.name: Volcanic
environments.description: Areas with active or dormant volcanoes, lava fields, and geothermal features.

hazards.name: Lava
hazards.description: Contact with lava deals 10d10 fire damage per round. Even being within 5 feet of lava deals 2d10 fire damage from the intense heat.

hazards.name: Toxic Gases
hazards.description: Volcanic areas often emit toxic gases. A creature that enters an area with toxic gas must make a DC 15 Constitution saving throw or take 3d6 poison damage and be poisoned for 1 hour.

hazards.name: Unstable Ground
hazards.description: The ground near volcanic areas can be unstable. A creature moving across unstable ground must make a DC 12 Dexterity saving throw or fall into a fissure, taking 2d6 bludgeoning damage.

weatherTypes.name: Ash Fall
weatherTypes.description: Falling volcanic ash reduces visibility to 30 feet and can cause respiratory issues.

weatherTypes.name: Pyroclastic Flow
weatherTypes.description: A deadly cloud of superheated gas and rock. A creature caught in a pyroclastic flow must make a DC 20 Dexterity saving throw or take 10d10 fire damage and 5d10 bludgeoning damage.

weatherTypes.name: Intense Heat
weatherTypes.description: The ambient temperature is extremely high. Creatures must make a DC 15 Constitution saving throw every hour or gain one level of exhaustion.

day.description: The heat is most intense during the day, increasing the DC for Constitution saving throws against extreme heat by 5.

night.description: The glow from lava and magma provides dim light in many areas, and the heat remains dangerous.

environments.name: Ethereal Plane
environments.description: A misty, ghostly dimension that overlaps with the Material Plane.

hazards.name: Ethereal Currents
hazards.description: Strong currents in the Ethereal Plane can carry creatures away. A creature caught in an ethereal current must make a DC 15 Strength saving throw or be carried 3d6 × 10 feet in a random direction.

hazards.name: Planar Bleeding
hazards.description: Areas where other planes bleed into the Ethereal can expose creatures to those planes' hazards. A creature in such an area must make a DC 15 Charisma saving throw or be affected by the foreign plane's energy.

hazards.name: Ectoplasmic Entanglement
hazards.description: Concentrations of ectoplasm can entangle creatures. A creature that enters an area of dense ectoplasm must make a DC 13 Strength saving throw or be restrained.

weatherTypes.name: Ether Storm
weatherTypes.description: Swirling ethereal energy that can disorient creatures. A creature caught in an ether storm must make a DC 15 Wisdom saving throw or be confused for 1d4 rounds.

weatherTypes.name: Planar Convergence
weatherTypes.description: Areas where multiple planes converge, creating unpredictable magical effects. Spells cast in these areas have a 20% chance of producing a wild magic surge.

weatherTypes.name: Ethereal Calm
weatherTypes.description: The typical misty, quiet state of the Ethereal Plane. No adverse effects.

day.description: There is no true day or night in the Ethereal Plane, but the mists may thin slightly, allowing better visibility of the Material Plane.

night.description: The mists thicken, making it harder to perceive the Material Plane but easier to see other ethereal entities.
